member.summary: Draws a filled convex area with the specified relative coordinates.

remarks.para: For modes other than , only convex shapes will work (that is, a polygon whose angles are all less than or equal to 180 degrees).

In addition, thin, flat areas (e.g. less than half a pixel in height with a slope of zero) may not show up in some render modes (such as ). To include these, the should include a of 1.0 and a that is the same as the .

member.param: The visual settings used in the draw operation.
The horizontal positions for each point in the outline of the area, in relative coordinates.
The vertical positions for each point in the outline of the area, in relative coordinates.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.CursorBase
member.summary: Provides an abstract base class from which basic graph cursors are derived.
member.remarks:
This class provides basic functionality for all cursors.
Use the property to configure the way the cursor behaves when it is moved.
Cursors can display their position. Use the property to make the value label visible, and use the property to configure the appearance of the value label.
You can also specify an arbitrary to identify the cursor. Use the property to make the label visible, and use the property to configure the appearance of the label.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.CursorBase.GetCursorDragStartScreenPosition(System.Windows.Point,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the screen start position that a drag should use given the specified mouse screen position and context.
member.param: The mouse position on screen at the start of a drag operation.
The context object provided to .
member.remarks: The mouse position works as a starting position in most cases. However, if designing a cursor that can be used in a non-Cartesian or non-linear context (such as a or a logarithmic axis), then a screen position other than the mouse position may need to be used, since dragging calculations are done as a screen offset from the starting screen position.
member.returns: The drag start position used for the cursor.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.GraphBase
member.summary: Represents the base class for all graphs. This class provides the core functionality for managing and processing incoming data.
member.remarks:
Like the and properties on , provides the and properties to define the data displayed by the graph.
Each item in the collection corresponds to a plot displayed by the graph. Setting will automatically populate the collection, while using the collection directly allows for fine-grained management of the data passed to each plot.
The graph natively supports the following data and collection types:
Category Types
Numeric , , , , , , , , ,
Time , , ,
Composite , , , ,
Basic Collections 1D , 2D , ,
Waveform Collections , , ,
Charting Collections , ,
In addition to the built-in data types, graph data support can be extended through the use of .
When performing a memory-optimized read on an analog waveform in DAQmx 9.5 and earlier, only changes to the or of the analog waveform will cause the WPF graph controls to update. If your DAQmx task is not configured to use timing, call the method after the memory-optimized read to display the new waveform data in the WPF graph controls.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates the syntax used to bind the property of the graph to an external source. In order for the graph to bind the in this way, the DataContext of the graph must be set to the object which defines the property being bound to. In this example the graph inherits the DataContext from that of its containing panel.
public class GraphModel { public ChartCollection<double> MyDataSource { get; set; } }
<ni:Grid x:Name="LayoutRoot" > <ni:Grid.DataContext > <ni:GraphModel /> </ni:Grid.DataContext >
<ni:Graph DataSource="{Binding MyDataSource}" /> </ni:Grid>

member.summary: Reprocesses data in the graph.
member.param: When using , controls whether new data objects or all data is reprocessed.
member.remarks:
When is used to pass data to a graph, you can pass for to only process new objects in the data source, or you can pass for to reprocess all items in the data source.
When is used to pass data to a graph, will always reprocess all data and the parameter is ignored.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.GraphConfiguration
member.summary: Contains advanced configuration options for graph controls and control parts.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.GraphConfiguration.DrawVisualCacheSizeProperty
member.summary: Identifies the attached property.
member.returns: The identifier for the attached property.

attachedmember.name: DrawVisualCacheSize
attachedmember.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating the size in kilobytes (KB) of for the cache for method.
attachedmember.value: A value indicating how much memory the given graph should allocate to storing values for re-use. The default value is 256 KB.

remarks.para: Re-rendering values takes a lot of effort from the CPU since each value is placed in TextBlock, laid out by WPF, rendered to a bitmap, then copied into the . This is all done on the UI thread, so responsiveness also slows for the entire WPF window. Caching reduces UI thread CPU usage by more than 500x.

At the standard WPF 12pt font, a 2-digit hexadecimal value takes about 0.85 KB. The default value therefore has enough space to store all possible 2-digit hexadecimal values. If an application has many of these graphs, then reducing this amount may be advisable to reduce memory usage.
Changing this value does not immediately update the existing cache; the cache is updated the next time the graph gets new data, or is called.
This does not apply to a of , which does not cache values. Also, cache is not pre-allocated; if DrawValue is never used, no cache will be allocated.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.LayeredGraph.Children
member.summary: Gets the collection of child objects to display in the graph.
member.value: The collection of child objects to display in the graph.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates how to add graph-aware objects, like s and s, to the plot area of a graph.
<ni:Graph.Children> <ni:Cursor TargetBrush="Red" TargetShape="Diamond" CrosshairBrush="Blue" /> <ni:PointAnnotation Fill="Green" TargetShape="Diamond" ArrowBrush="Yellow" /> </ni:Graph.Children>

The following example demonstrates how to add arbitrary UI objects to the plot area of a graph.
<ni:Graph.Children> <!-- RelativePanel attached properties can be used to stretch a UI element across the entire plot area --> <ni:Image Source="map.png" RelativePanel.RelativeWidth="1.0" RelativePanel.RelativeHeight="1.0" /> </ni:Graph.Children>

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.PlotBase
member.summary: Provides an abstract base class for all two-dimensional plots.
member.remarks:
A plot in a graph defines how the associated data in the collection is scaled and rendered.
Use the property to prevent a plot from displaying the associated data. Use the property to identify a plot when it appears in a .

member.summary: Gets or sets the renderer used to draw the data associated with the plot.
member.value: The renderer used to draw the data associated with the plot. The default value is .
member.example:
This example shows how to configure the Renderer property.
<!-- Single renderer --> <ni:Plot> <ni:Plot.Renderer> <ni:LinePlotRenderer Stroke="Blue" /> </ni:Plot.Renderer> </ni:Plot>
<!-- Multiple renderers. Note that the last renderer has the highest z-order. --> <ni:Plot> <ni:PlotRendererGroup> <ni:LinePlotRenderer Stroke="Blue" /> <ni:PointPlotRenderer Fill="Blue" /> </ni:PlotRendererGroup> </ni:Plot>

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.PlotRenderer
member.summary: Represents an abstract base class for plot renderers.
member.remarks:
Plot renderers are used to display the data associated with a plot after it has been processed by a graph. You can use a plot renderer by assigning it to the property of a in a graph, or by adding it to the collection of default plot renderers on or .
Requirements are verified by the graph using reference equality.
When deriving from , create the data requirements once in the constructor for the renderer, and return the same instance for every call to .

member.remarks:
The parent graph control will retrieve the once, and will re-query the requirements whenever new data is assigned, or a invalidation event occurs.
Requirements are verified by the graph using reference equality.
When deriving from , create the data requirements once in the constructor for the renderer, and return the same instance for every call to .

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.PhosphorBrushExtension
member.summary: Generates a from the specified brush and phosphor .
member.remarks: Use the phosphor brush extension in XAML on the brush properties of a to enabled the phosphor effect in a graph.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates how to use to apply a phosphor brush to line plot renderers in a graph.
<ni:Graph> <ni:Graph.Resources> <ni:FadeRamp x:Key="BlueRamp" Color="Blue" Duration="1000" DurationKind="Time" /> </ni:Graph.Resources>
<ni:Graph.Plots> <ni:Plot Label="Fade from Green to Transparent"> <ni:LinePlotRenderer Stroke="{PhosphorBrush Green}" /> </ni:Plot> <ni:Plot Label="Render Black line, then fade to Blue"> <ni:LinePlotRenderer Stroke="{PhosphorBrush Black, {StaticResource BlueRamp}}" /> </ni:Plot> </ni:Graph.Plots> </ni:Graph>

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.PhosphorMode
member.summary: Specifies phosphor modes for brushes.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.PhosphorMode.None
member.summary: Indicates the brush is always used, and will never be replaced by color data from the phosphor ramp.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.PhosphorMode.Immediate
member.summary: Indicates the brush is ignored, and only the phosphor ramp is used for color data.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.PhosphorMode.Deferred
member.summary: Indicates the brush is used for the first frame, and will be replaced by color data from the phosphor ramp on the next update.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.PhosphorMode.Paused
member.summary: Indicates the first frame brush value is used to draw new data, leaving any existing phosphor values unchanged.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.RenderInvalidatedEventArgs
member.summary: Provides data for the event.
member.remarks:
If invalidation was caused by a change in appearance, use to notify all rendering systems to re-render.
If invalidation was caused by a change of position only (the appearance has not changed), use to notify only rendering systems that use position information to re-render.
If invalidate includes changes to both appearance and position, use .

member.summary: Gets an instance representing a invalidation reason.

member.summary: Gets an instance representing a invalidation reason.
member.value: A instance with a value of .

member.summary: Gets the reason for raising the event.

member.summary: Specifies the reasons that an was raised.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.RenderInvalidatedReasons.VisualChange
member.summary: Indicates invalidation was caused by a change in appearance.
member.remarks: All rendering systems need to re-render.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.RenderInvalidatedReasons.PositionalChange
member.summary: Indicates invalidation was caused by a change of position only (the appearance has not changed).
member.remarks: Only rendering systems that use position information need to re-render.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.RenderInvalidatedReasons.VisualAndPositionalChange
member.summary: Indicates invalidation was caused by a change in both appearance and position.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.RenderInvalidatedReasons.LayerChange
member.summary: Indicates invalidation was caused by a change in layers.
member.remarks: Rendering systems that use the same in multiple layers (such as ) need to re-render, taking care to fully clear the renderer first to ensure visuals are not added to multiple layers due to sequential ordering of calls.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Axis`1
member.summary: Defines the look and behavior of an axis on a graph.
member.typeparam: The data type of the axis.
member.remarks:
The property determines whether to associate the axis with the x-domain or y-domain of a graph.
By default, Cartesian graphs are set to use an with a value of .
member.example:
The following example demonstrates configuring an axis on a graph. This example uses an in the XAML, which is equivalent to Axis<double>.
<ni:Graph> <ni:Graph.Axes> <ni:AxisDouble Orientation="Horizontal" Range="0,30" Adjuster="None" Label="Time" Location="Near"> <ni:AxisDouble.MajorGridLines> <ni:GridLines Stroke="Red" /> </ni:AxisDouble.MajorGridLines> </ni:AxisDouble> <ni:AxisDouble Orientation="Vertical" Adjusted="FitExactly" Label="Voltage" Location="Far" InteractionMode="ReadOnly" /> </ni:Graph.Axes> </ni:Graph>

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.ChartCollection`2
member.summary: Represents a collection of index and sample chart data values.
member.typeparam: The type of index data stored in the chart collection.
The type of sample data stored in the chart collection.
member.remarks:
Use the class to chart numeric data in a graph.
The index values added to the chart collection must be strictly increasing, though the interval between individual values can be arbitrary. To have index values added automatically, use the class.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.ChartCollectionAnalogWaveform`1
member.summary: Represents a collection of chart data formed from sources.
member.typeparam: The type of the waveform data stored in the collection.
member.remarks:
Use the class to chart data in a graph.
The type of timing data passed to the graph is determined by the or properties on the appended waveforms. Each waveform must have the same timing type, and must start after the last timing value of the previous waveform.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.ChartCollectionAnalogWaveform`1.Append(NationalInstruments.AnalogWaveform{`0})
member.summary: Appends the data in an to the collection.
member.param: The containing the data to add.
member.remarks:
After appending the new elements to the chart collection, this method raises the event.
The first time a waveform is appended to the collection, the type of timing information used by the waveform is stored (precision timing, normal timing, or none). All additional waveforms added must use the same kind of timing.
member.exception:
The timing of does not match the timing of the last waveform added.
-or-
The timing of starts at a value less than or equal to the end time of the last waveform added.

member.summary: Represents the third axis on an intensity plot, where colors are used to represent data values.

Use the collection to define the range of values displayed by the scale, and how each value is mapped to a color within the scale. Use the and properties to define the colors used for data that falls outside the range of .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.ColorScale.IsInterpolated
member.summary: Gets or sets the interpolation behavior indicating how a value maps to a color if the value does not match an entry in the collection.
member.value:
A Boolean value that indicates how the color is calculated for values that do not match entries in the collection.
If , the color is calculated by taking a weighted mean of the colors associated with the color map entry values immediately above and below the value.
If , the color associated with the nearest lower color map entry value is used.
The default value is .

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Cursor
member.summary: Represents a cursor that can display a single value in a graph.
member.remarks:
In addition to the basic members provided by , you can configure the appearance of the in several different ways.
Use the , , and properties to change the color, width, and length of the crosshair lines. The , , and properties determine the shape, color, and size of the value target.
Use and to associate the cursor with a particular data value in a plot. Use , , and to restrict the cursor to only a single plot or group of plots. The current value displayed by the cursor can be read from the property.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.DigitalGraph
member.summary: Represents a graph control that displays digital data.
member.remarks: Plots control how data in the graph is rendered. The and determine how the data is scaled. The displayed data can be navigated through pan and zoom methods, both programmatically and interactively. Additional methods allow finding visual parts of the graph through hit testing, and mapping between screen and relative coordinates.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.DigitalGraph.PlotAreaMargin
member.summary: Gets or sets the margin around the plot area used to display scales.
member.value: The margin around the plot area used to display scales. The default value is a containing values.
member.remarks: When data is passed to the graph at a high rate, causing the scale ranges to change quickly, the repeated resizing of the plot area can degrade UI performance. Setting this property to a with fixed values (such as the value from after the graph has been displayed) will avoid these resize issues, preventing repeated re-drawing of the data.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Graph
member.summary: Represents a graph control that displays data in a Cartesian coordinate system.
member.remarks:
Plots control how data in the graph is rendered. Scales associated with a plot determine how the data for that plot is scaled. The displayed data can be navigated through pan and zoom methods, both programmatically and interactively. Additional methods allow finding visual parts of the graph through hit testing, and mapping between screen and relative coordinates.
When performing a memory-optimized read on an analog waveform in NI-DAQmx 9.5 and earlier, only changes to the or of the analog waveform cause the WPF graph controls to update. If your NI-DAQmx task is not configured to use timing, call the method after the memory-optimized read to display the new waveform data in the WPF graph controls.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates how to configure the plots for a graph, including custom renderers for each plot, and explicit associations for which vertical scale to use.
Because only one horizontal axis exists, each plot will automatically use it for their horizontal dimension without the need for an explicit association. If two horizontal axes were declared, the plots would only use the first horizontal axis unless an explicit association was made (similarly for vertical axes).
<ni:Graph> <ni:Graph.Axes> <ni:AxisDouble x:Name="xAxis" Orientation="Horizontal" /> <ni:AxisDouble x:Name="yAxis1" Orientation="Vertical" /> <ni:AxisDouble x:Name="yAxis2" Orientation="Vertical" /> </ni:Graph.Axes> <ni:Graph.Plots> <ni:Plot VerticalScale="{Binding ElementName=yAxis1}" > <ni:LinePlotRenderer Stroke="Green" StrokeThickness="2" StrokeDashArray="1 2" /> </ni:Plot> <ni:Plot VerticalScale="{Binding ElementName=yAxis2}" > <ni:PointPlotRenderer Fill="Red" Shape="Ellipse" Size="5, 5" /> </ni:Plot> </ni:Graph.Plots> </ni:Graph>

The following example shows how to set up a graph to use a set of default renderers in the absence of either a plot itself for a particular trace of data, or a plot that has its Renderer set to .
Assuming the graph is given multi-plot data, the first trace of data would use the specified (a in this case). The second trace of data would start with the second renderer in the collection, and any further traces of data would cycle through the collection from there (the third trace would use the , the fourth would cycle to the , and so on).
<ni:Graph> <ni:Graph.DefaultPlotRenderers> <ni:BarPlotRenderer Fill="Blue" /> <ni:PointPlotRenderer Fill="Red" /> <ni:LinePlotRenderer Stroke="Green" /> </ni:Graph.DefaultPlotRenderers> <ni:Graph.Plots> <ni:Plot> <ni:LinePlotRenderer /> </ni:Plot> </ni:Graph.Plots> </ni:Graph>

member.remarks: When data is passed to the graph at a high rate, causing the scale ranges to change quickly, the repeated resizing of the plot area can degrade UI performance. Setting this property to a with fixed values (such as the value from after the graph has been displayed) will avoid these resize issues, preventing repeated re-drawing of the data.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.GraphEditInteraction
member.summary: Provides a mechanism for drawing data into an .
member.remarks:
The behavior of the interaction relies on and that are passed to the method.
When is , a new set of data is drawn into the , and automatically updates to the plot representing that data.
When is set to a valid value and is , automatically updates to the set of data closest to . When is , the interaction only affects the data specified by .

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.GraphInteraction
member.summary: Defines the basic interaction functionality for the .
member.remarks:
The table below describes each of the interactions provided by :
Interaction Description
No interaction. Modifier Key: None
The plot area can be zoomed by dragging the mouse. Modifier Key:
The plot area can be zoomed horizontally by dragging the mouse. Modifier Key:
The plot area can be zoomed vertically by dragging the mouse. Modifier Key:
The plot area can be zoomed in around a point by clicking the mouse. Modifier Key: None
The plot area can be zoomed out around a point by clicking the mouse. Modifier Key: None
The plot area can be panned by dragging the mouse. Modifier Key:
The plot area can be panned horizontally by dragging the mouse. Modifier Key:
The plot area can be panned vertically by dragging the mouse. Modifier Key:
When an interaction is included in the collection, you can use the interaction by holding down the modifier key listed in the table above. The first interaction with that modifier key will be used.
When an interaction is set on the property, you can use the interaction without holding down any modifier key. The can be used to set the property at runtime.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.IntensityGraph
member.summary: Represents a graph control that displays three-dimensional data in a two-dimensional Cartesian coordinate system, with color representing the third dimension.
member.remarks:
and determine how the data coordinates are scaled, and determines how the third dimension of data is mapped to color values.
By default, the intensity graph is configured to use an with a data type of to support a two-dimensional data source. For this kind of dense data source, each row and column index in the 2D array is used for the X and Y coordinates of the corresponding array value.
The intensity graph also supports collections of sparse data. Since there are no regular index values for sparse data, the size of the color rectangles is controlled by the and properties.
Although the intensity graph supports only a single plot, you can achieve more advanced combinations of intensity and other data by using an with the control.
member.example:
This example shows how to configure the color scale of an intensity graph in XAML.
<ni:IntensityGraph> <ni:IntensityGraph.ColorScale> <ni:ColorScale LowColor="Red" HighColor="Green"> <ni:ColorScale.Markers> <ni:ColorScaleMarker Value="0.0" Color="Yellow" /> <ni:ColorScaleMarker Value="0.5" Color="White" /> <ni:ColorScaleMarker Value="1.0" Color="Blue" /> </ni:ColorScale.Markers> </ni:ColorScale> </ni:IntensityGraph.ColorScale> </ni:IntensityGraph>

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Legend
member.summary: Represents a legend control used to display symbols and descriptions of another object, such as the plots or cursors of a graph.
member.remarks:
A legend control displays symbols and labels for a specific set of elements provided through the property, such as the plots or cursors of a graph.
To bind a specific set of elements, such as all the plots on a , bind to the collection. To display every element in a graph, bind to the graph itself. contains the collection of all objects that are displayed in the legend.
The size and background of each symbol in the legend control are determined by the and properties. To match how an object is displayed in the plot area of a graph, bind to the of the graph.

member.param: An item to filter.
member.returns: if should be displayed in the legend; otherwise, .
member.remarks: The default implementation filters out instances, which cannot appear in the visual tree more than once. This method is used to set the property.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.MixedGraph
member.summary: Represents a graph control that displays analog and digital data.
member.remarks: Plots control how data in the graph is rendered. The scales determine how the data is scaled. The displayed data can be navigated through pan and zoom methods, both programmatically and interactively. Additional methods allow finding visual parts of the graph through hit testing, and mapping between screen and relative coordinates.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.MultiPlotCursor
member.summary: Represents a cursor that is associated with values from multiple plots using an axis in a graph.
member.remarks:
In addition to the basic members provided by , you can configure the appearance of the in several different ways.
Use the and properties to change the color and width of the crosshair line. The , , and properties determine the shape, color, and size of the value targets.
Use the property to orient the cursor and display values from all plots that use the axis. Use the property to position the cursor along the axis. The current values displayed by the cursor can be read from the collection.

member.summary: Defines how a plot of data is scaled and displayed in a Cartesian graph.
member.remarks: Use the and properties to control how the data associated with the plot is scaled to fit within the plot area of the graph. If no scales are specified, default values will be retrieved from the parent .

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.PointAnnotation
member.summary: Represents an annotation that highlights a data point in a graph.
member.remarks:
In addition to the basic members provided by , you can configure the appearance of the in several different ways.
Use and to position the annotation on a specific data point along the and in the graph.
Use the , , , and properties to change the shape, size, and color of the annotation visual.
Use the property to position the in relation to the annotation visual, and use the , , , and properties to change the color, shape, and size of the arrow drawn from the to the annotation visual.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.PolarAngularAxis
member.summary: Represents the angular axis on a polar graph.
member.remarks:
The contains properties that determine how data values are scaled, where tick marks and labels are placed, and how grid lines are drawn.
By default, the angular axis is configured to display data with . To display data in radians, set the property to .

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.PolarGraph
member.summary: Represents a graph control that displays data in a Polar coordinate system.
member.remarks:
Plots control how data in the graph is rendered. The and determine how the data is scaled.
When given or data, the polar graph will automatically use the and values from the data. When given data, the polar graph assumes that the and values from the data are in the appropriate domain for the and , respectively.
By default, the polar graph is configured to display data in degrees. To display data in radians, set the property to a with a of .

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.PolarGraph.Zoom(System.Double)
member.summary: Performs a zoom along the radius axis.
member.param: The relative amount with which to modify the radius axis.
member.remarks: The minimum of the axis range is unaffected by this call. For example, a Zoom(0.5) on an axis with a range of [0, 10] causes the axis range to change to [0, 5].

member.summary: Represents a cursor that is associated with a range of values along axes in a graph.

In addition to the basic members provided by , you can configure the appearance of the in several different ways.
Use the , , and properties to change the outline and color of the range area.
Use the , , , and properties to control the initial position of the cursor. If only one range is set, the cursor will draw to infinity for the other range. The current range displayed by the cursor can be read from the and properties.
